title: 107_s3079
content: The Act may be cited as the "Iraqi Scientists Immigration Act of 2002" and allows for the admission of critical aliens. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include a new subparagraph (W) allowing for the admission of aliens who have worked in an Iraqi program to produce weapons. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow for the admission of aliens who have worked in an Iraqi program to produce weapons of mass destruction or the means to deliver them, and who possess critical information and are willing to provide it to the United States Government or international inspectors. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow for the admission of aliens who have worked in an Iraqi program related to weapons of mass destruction, possess critical information, and are willing to provide it to the US Government or international inspectors. This includes individuals who may be in danger due to providing such information and those whose admission is in the public interest or national security. Additionally, family members of these aliens may also be eligible for admission. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow for the admission of aliens with critical information related to weapons of mass destruction in the public interest or national security. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to set numerical limitations and conditions for nonimmigrants admitted under section 101(a)(15)(W), with a total limit of 500 admissions. Nonimmigrants must report information to the Attorney General and avoid criminal offenses punishable by imprisonment of 1 year or more. Nonimmigrants admitted under section 101(a)(15)(W) must cooperate with the US Government, waive the right to contest removal before obtaining lawful permanent resident status, and disclose information on Iraqi weapons programs. Nonimmigrants admitted under section 101(a)(15)(W) must cooperate with the US Government, waive the right to contest removal before obtaining lawful permanent resident status, and disclose information on Iraqi weapons programs. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include adjustment to permanent resident status for "W" nonimmigrants. Nonimmigrant admitted under section 101(a)(15)(W)(i) may have their status adjusted to that of a lawful permanent resident if they have complied with section 214(s) since admission. The Attorney General, in coordination with other officials, has the discretion to make this adjustment. The Attorney General may record an alien's lawful admission for permanent residence upon approval, reducing the number of visas issued for the fiscal year. Additionally, the Attorney General has the discretion to waive inadmissibility grounds for nonimmigrants in the interest of national security or public interest. Section 248(1) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include waivers for inadmissibility grounds for nonimmigrants in the interest of national security. The term "weapon of mass destruction" is defined in this Act according to the Defense Against Weapons of Mass Destruction Act of 1996. A technical correction was made to include biological agents, toxins, or vectors in the definition. This was passed by the Senate on November 20, 2002.
